Bill Rohan.Action: Leads imaginative play with his sister, creatively directing the game with confidence and detail.
Instinctively senses a change in atmosphere at the sound of the lawn mower stopping and goes to check on his parents, showing situational awareness.
Tells Sue to stop singing a nonsensical song, indicating irritation towards her innocence.
Turns to sister Sue after hearing her singing, showing attention and awareness of his sister.
Calls out excitedly about German planes, insists he saw them despite others' disbelief.
Subjected to Dawn's playful but aggressive hitting and teasing.
Calls out warning of German planes, but no planes are seen; insists on seeing them despite others' disbelief.
Displays confidence in his observation but is contradicted and physically reprimanded by sister; shows poor judgment in misinformation.
Clutches his submerged foot in mock agony inside the flooded air-raid shelter, indicating playful behavior rather than a practical response.
Walks barefoot towards the house carrying wet socks and shoes, listens attentively to others discussing difficult choices.
Carries his wet socks and shoes barefoot towards the house, calmly wrings the water from his socks while listening thoughtfully to the conversation about the children's future.
No clear action showing skill or decisiveness in the excerpt; mostly passive and reflective presence.
Tries to conceal his anxiety from his sister by shrugging.
Plays a playful yet ineffective prank on Dawn by pretending there's a soldier at the door, which she immediately recognizes as a lie.
Attempts to wake Dawn and convince her it is dinner time, showing some initiative and confidence.
Swings on the leather straps of the Sam Browne with Sue, showing discomfort and sensing something dangerous and alien in their father’s role.
Slips into the garden and looks up at the leaden sky imploringly, showing hope or anxious anticipation during the news broadcast.
Bites hard into the Sam Browne belt, pleased with the marks he leaves on the leather.
Drifts over to his lead soldiers, perhaps showing affection or care toward them.
Sinks his teeth into the Sam Browne belt, biting hard and pleased with the impression made, showing tactile engagement and a confident appreciation of the war relic.
Drifts over to his lead soldiers spread out in a corner of the room, showing a thoughtful attendance to his miniature troops and possibly reflecting on leadership or strategy.
Walks close and examines sleeping elderly men (his father and Clive) with attentive interest, compares photo of his father as a young man to his current self.
Tries to rouse his father to listen to the news despite being told to 'go off and play'.
Shouts alarm about the Germans landing to wake his father and others, showing concern and alertness.
Admits he was only joking after alarming his family, which causes alarm to others.
Shares earphones and listens to radio shows with his sister, displaying companionship and closeness.
Ventures out with his sister to observe the situation, showing curiosity and shared courage.
Feels it is his duty to wake up his father about the news, shows initiative and responsibility.
Shouts an alarm about the Germans landing but then admits he was only joking, which alarms others unnecessarily.
Shares earphones and listens attentively to the radio amid the chaos, showing composure and calm observation.
Gets up and investigates the noises outside his room quietly, showing curiosity and caution.
Puts a protective arm about Sue when she is upset.
Comforts Sue by saying they won't be like those hardened soldiers when they grow up.
Shows unconcern when finding the bodies of Clive and Mac on the battlefield, eats mud after wiping it off his father's uniform.
Pretends to drive the car and makes driving noises to comfort Sue.
Engages playfully in back-and-forth with Sue about driving the car.
Sits in the driving seat pretending to drive, making all the right noises.
Assures Sue that he can drive the car home, responding confidently to her doubts.
Makes a face, disgusted by the show of sentiment between Clive and Grace.
Helps Clive put the car on blocks and takes off the wheels.
Helps Clive put the car on blocks and take off the wheels, showing practical involvement and willingness to assist.
Makes a face, disgusted by the show of sentiment between Clive and Grace, indicating possible social awkwardness or lack of emotional intelligence in sensitive moments.
Experimenting with the cricket ball, showing eagerness to learn and engage with his father.
Calling out to his father as he departs, showing attachment and longing.
Tries to catch the ball thrown back by his father but loses nerve and lets it fall, feeling shame.
Nods knowledgeably when shown how to flick the ball with off-break and leg-break.
Experiments with flicking the ball this way and that after receiving instruction.
Loses nerve and jumps back, failing to catch the ball thrown by his father, showing hesitation and a momentary lack of confidence.
Wince and appear uncomfortable while being passed from hand to hand and hugged excessively by female relatives.
Fights back tears and is emotionally affected when saying goodbye to his mother, turning away embarrassed when she wants a kiss.
Fights back tears and turns away embarrassed when his mother wants a kiss from him.
Casts a pleading look to MAC to get rescued from overwhelming family attention.
Passively endures the chaotic and overwhelming environment without taking control or initiative.
Struggles to get free when Mac tries to rescue him and Sue from the enclosure, expressing a desire to leave quickly and embarrassed by the public scene.
Fights back tears and turns away embarrassed when his mother wants a kiss from him.
Struggles to get free of Mac who hoists him out of the pen, showing resistance or lack of calmness.
Expresses that he wants to leave despite the public scene, showing assertiveness but also impulsiveness.
Watches Grace sensitively, aware of her mood before discussing the war map.
Takes it upon himself to update the war map, fulfilling his 'mournful duty'.
Carefully attaches model airplane wings, indicating patience and focus.
Conscientiously updates the war map, showing awareness of changing situations and responsibility.
Considers moving the German army pins on the map promptly, showing initiative and attentiveness.
Accepts Grace's suggestion to delay moving the pins until morning, showing willingness to negotiate but possibly hesitating in decisive action.
Scampers in quickly at Dawn's call to listen to the wireless broadcast, showing alertness and responsiveness.
Looks at his mother with concern during the propaganda broadcast, indicating awareness and understanding of the situation.
Protests being sent to bed by Grace but is silenced, showing a limited ability to assert himself in stressful situations.
Seizes Dawn from behind to stop her dangerous play, engages in giggling and playful behavior.
Cocks an ear to listen carefully to the sounds of anti-aircraft guns and bombs, shows alertness and protectiveness.
Quickly recognizes the sound of anti-aircraft guns ('Flak') and correctly assesses the type of bombing ('Basket bombing').
Reacts protectively and playfully to Dawn's prank by seizing her and pulling her back, showing awareness and immediate response.
Counts steadily between bombs, helping maintain calm during air raid.
Scrambles after Dawn when she tries to leave the shelter, showing concern for her safety.
Hesitates before joining Dawn outside, indicating caution or internal conflict.
Plays with hot shrapnel, showing curiosity but not recklessness.
Keeps counting between bomb explosions calmly and steadily, helping maintain focus during a tense situation.
Hesitates in the porch before running outside after Dawn, showing some momentary uncertainty in a crisis.
Immediately notices and picks up hot shrapnel, indicating alertness and awareness in a dangerous environment.
Hears a groaning voice from a bomb site and ventures forward to investigate.
Finds two people trapped and runs off to get help despite the deserted street and danger.
Notices a voice crying from the bomb site, ventures forward to assess situation despite danger.
Realizes he cannot help directly, runs up the street to seek help.
Flinches and winces as the cane strikes his hand, showing fear and anxious anticipation but no attempt to resist or understand the reason behind the punishment.
Mesmerized and fearful, appears vulnerable and passive during the Headmaster's war rhetoric instead of critically engaging or reacting confidently.
Jerks convulsively and grins as the cane connects, indicating a submissive acceptance or coping mechanism rather than assertive or skillful behavior.
Stands up confidently to answer the teacher's question about the British Empire, showing knowledge and composure despite recent physical punishment.
Covertly shows the welts on his hands to a neighbor, indicating awareness and discretion about his suffering.
Hides emotional distress behind his gasmask, ultimately breaking down to tears, and sticks out his tongue at the Headmaster.
Runs excitedly with children to watch the balloon launch, shares their laughter and enjoyment.
Is totally engrossed watching the newsreel, simulates engine noises playfully, showing engagement and childlike enthusiasm.
Expresses desire to see the end of the film despite the air raid warning, showing reluctance to leave and shared interest with others.
Is totally engrossed, enthralled, and simulates engine noise out of habit while watching the newsreel about the Battle of Britain.
Expresses a desire to see the end of the newsreel despite an air raid warning, showing some lack of practical judgment or situational awareness.
Watches the dogfight with neighbors, including children, in a calm and composed manner.
Watches the aerial combat calmly with others, does not panic or act rashly during the dogfight and aftermath.
Joins the neighbors to observe the parachuting pilot but does not take any visible initiative or proactive action afterward.
Patiently tries to draw a stocking seam on Dawn's leg, despite difficulty and repeated attempts.
Hesitates to draw the seam higher, showing reluctance to go beyond what he thinks necessary.
Carefully attempts to draw a stocking seam, attentive to detail and willing to redo his work when corrected.
Hesitates and stops halfway up the thigh, showing some lack of thoroughness or confidence to complete the task fully.
Imagines himself as a Spitfire pilot escaping enemy fire, showing vivid and skillful mental visualization.
Wakes up confused and reacts to Dawn climbing through his window, indicating a lack of alertness or situational awareness.
Whispers 'Mind that shrapnel' to Dawn, showing care for his belongings and attentiveness.
Is impressed by Dawn's acquisition of a Canadian hat badge, showing interest and engagement.
Bumps down the stairs half asleep during an air-raid alert, suggesting a certain absent-mindedness or lack of urgency.
Handles shrapnel collection carefully and appreciates the significance of the badge Dawn shows him.
Is half asleep and bumbling down the stairs during an air raid warning, indicating sluggish or unprepared behavior.
Bumps down the stairs half asleep, appears clumsy and not alert.
Is quickly evacuated through the broken windows by Grace, with no indication of taking proactive or protective actions himself.
Does not display any signs of skill, confidence, or intelligent response to the bombing and chaos; largely passive and dependent on others.
Watches the emotional interaction between Grace and Dawn with perplexity and detachment, not intervening to comfort or engage.
Ventures outside with Sue to explore damage, showing engagement and inclusion of child.
Watches the complex emotional interplay between Grace and Dawn with perplexity, showing detachment and lack of understanding of emotional nuance.
Ventures outside with Sue to explore the damage done to Rosehill Avenue after a night of bombing, showing initiative and engagement with the situation.
Lashes back violently at Roger when jabbed in the ribs, scaring and quelling the group of children.
Refutes Roger's assertion that Pauline's mother was killed without verifying facts, acting out of disbelief.
Responds with violent anger to Roger's teasing, intimidating the boy and silencing the group.
Nudges Sue to encourage her to invite Pauline to play despite Pauline's refusal and evident grief.
Watches carefully from a distance and does not directly approach Pauline himself, deflecting the task to Sue.
Encourages sister to approach and try to include a troubled child (Pauline) in play despite the child's clear refusal.
Distracted by kneading the putty while others are engaged in practical tasks like repairing windows, showing a lack of focus and contribution.
Refuses to tell the story about Pauline's mum when prompted by Sue, saying 'Not now. They wouldn't believe me.'
Wanders alone among bomb ruins, appearing vulnerable and curious, looking for shrapnel.
Honest and denies spying when accused by the boys despite their threats and rough treatment.
Fights back tears when physically intimidated and restrained by the boys, showing vulnerability rather than aggression.
Refuses to talk about Pauline's mum, claiming others wouldn't believe him.
Wanders among bomb ruins to scavenge for shrapnel despite obvious danger.
Maintains composure and denies spying under intimidation and physical threat.
Allows himself to be caught, restrained, and blindfolded by a gang of boys without apparent resistance or escape attempt.
Shares secret information to warn others about dangers, showing concern and responsibility.
Refuses to immediately say swear words when asked, showing restraint and sincerity rather than just mimicking peer pressure.
Forces himself to say a swear word to join the gang, showing willingness to connect even if uncomfortable.
Shares useful intelligence from his uncle at the War Office about dangers on bomb sites, capturing the attention of the group.
Fails to verbalize swear words when initially challenged, showing hesitation and discomfort.
Eventually learns and repeats the swear words correctly, proving adaptability.
Joins in destructive behavior with gang, showing excitement in pent-up aggression.
Questions practicality of enemy confusion plan, showing pragmatic skepticism rather than playful participation.
Initially tentative about destructive behavior but quickly becomes more violent and aggressive than others.
Questions practicality of sabotaging sign-posts by asking if the enemy will have maps.
His face is tense with apprehension as he awaits his turn in a humiliating act; shows vulnerability.
Loses temper and throws a stone in anger after witnessing a distressing and intimate scene involving Dawn; shows emotional turmoil but also a harsh reaction.
Leads the gang in throwing stones aggressively and confidently in an angry impulse.
Reads a comic and takes a punch bravely, showing resilience but not necessarily skill or intelligence.
Distributes received goods thoughtfully and generously among family members.
Denies kinship with a girl identified as potentially his sister, possibly out of embarrassment or denial.
Plays along horseplay with Bruce, appearing relaxed and engaged in social interaction.

Jumps for joy with Sue upon seeing the jam, showing enthusiasm and quick emotional response.

Questions the destruction of the balloon with genuine regret.

Is disturbed by the music and the emotional display, but remains observant and calm, redirecting focus to the paintings on the wall.

Expresses amazement ('Wow!') without further insight when hearing about the Big Berthas' shelling range and expense.

Remains calm next to the firechief and assesses what possessions might be safe, showing practical awareness.

Charges and physically confronts Roger, successfully defending against the bigger boy with ferocity.
Shows acute embarrassment and fails to hide his emotions when others watch the family's misfortune.
Asks to learn sculling from Grandfather George and holds his hand to mimic the stroke.
Studies Grandfather George's sculling technique attentively and asks to try, showing willingness to learn and engage with a new skill.
Holds Grandfather George's hand and moves in unison, demonstrating ability to follow guidance carefully and coordinate movements.

Responds to Dawn's request to listen to her stomach, despite reluctance; shares a playful moment with her.
Comes quietly and respectfully into the dining room, taking his seat without disturbing others.

Observes that the rat was likely hit and reports it calmly to Grandfather George, showing attention to detail and composed observation.
Suppresses his laughter after making the comment about the rat, showing social awareness and emotional control.

Hangs on to the pole despite Grandfather George's advice to let go, showing determination but also causing difficulty.
Clings to the pole when stuck and waits for help, demonstrating trust in Grandfather George and willingness to collaborate.

Successfully steps neatly onto the rear decking after grandfather’s efforts and ferries his aunts to the island, rear-sculling with some difficulty but well enough.

Engages in friendly cricket game with Grandfather George, showing playful competitiveness and sharing a light moment.

Responds to humiliation by mouthing swear words, which may represent poor emotional control or unproductive reaction.

Rescues Bruce's cap after it floats away and stays calm when Bruce disappears underwater.

Cheering louder than anyone else during the school celebration despite previously being sullen.

Showing morose and sullen demeanor during the car ride to school, reflecting low confidence and disengagement.
Internalizing dislike for the local school and teacher but ultimately attending school, showing passive acceptance without resistance or problem-solving.
